fr:mainmatter.html:p: Furthermore, if a_{i,i}=0, then we call \mathbf {A} Strictly Upper Triangular.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Invariant subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 5.2
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator on V. We call a subspace U\subseteq V Invariant under L if for each u\in U we have L(u)\in U.
That is to say, the image of every vector in U under L remains in U. So L(U)\subseteq U.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definitions 5.5 and 5.8
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} is an Eigenvalue of L if there is a non-zero vector u\in V such that L(u)=\lambda u. The vector u is called an Eigenvector of L corresponding to eigenvalue \lambda .
Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 5.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} be an eigenvalue of L. Then we define the Eigenspace of L to be V_{\lambda }=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\lambda v\}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let V\neq \{0\} be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L has at least one eigenvalue.

Let n=\dim (V), let v\in V be a nonzero vector. We have the collection of vectors \{V, Tv, T^{2}v, …, T^{n}v\} Since this contains n+1 vectors, it must be linearly dependent. Then there exists scalars a_{0},a_{1},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} not all zero, such that 0=a_{0}v+a_{1}Lv+a_{2}L^{2}v+…+a_{n}L^{n}v Let m be the largest index such that a_{m}
eq 0 (so all a_{k}=0 for k>m and we can just drop these terms). Since v
eq 0, we must have m>0 (and even possibly m=n). Consider the polynomial p(z)=a_{0}+a_{1}z+…+a_{m}z^{m}. Then using the immediate consequences of the fundamental theorem of algebra, we can factorize p(z) as p(z)=c(z-\lambda _{1})(…)(z-\lambda _{m}) where c,\lambda _{1},…,\lambda _{m}\in \mathbb {C} and c
eq 0.

Then 0=a_{0}v+a_{1}Lv+a_{2}L^{2}v+…+a_{n}L^{n}v=p(L)v and 0=p(L)v=c(L-\lambda _{1}I)(…)(L-\lambda _{m}I)v which means at least one of the factors L-\lambda _{j}I must be non-injective. This means \lambda _{j} must be an eigenvalue of L.
Furthermore, if a_{i,i}=0, then we call \mathbf {A} Strictly Upper Triangular.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If further m=n (so we have an n-by-n matrix), then we call it a Square Matrix. In this case, we can refer to the Main Diagonal as the components a_{1,1}, a_{2,2}, …, a_{n,n}.

We abbreviate "m-by-n matrix" as "m\times n matrix". The pair of numbers (m,n) is called the Dimensions of the matrix. (We can also extend our definitions to allow m or n to be zero, but these are degenerate edgecases.)
Also note, some people use parentheses in writing matrices, other people use square brackets. Both are acceptable.

If we want to refer to a generic component of an m-by-n matrix \mathbf {A}, we write \mathbf {A}=(a_{ij}) to indicate we will use a_{ij} to refer to the component found in the i^{\text {th}} row and j^{\text {th}} column.

Also, very important, if we have some m-by-n matrix \mathbf {A}=(a_{i,j}) and we wanted to refer to its component in row r, column c, we may refer to that component by writing (\mathbf {A})_{r,c}. This is, of course, the same as a_{r,c}, but it will be useful [much later] to take a matrix and refer to certain components without introducing (a_{i,j}) first.

For any positive integers m, n, we have the m\times n Zero Matrix to be the matrix whose components are all zero. We denote this by \mathbf {0} or 0 because it will play the analogous counterpart that 0\in \mathbb {R} plays.

For any positive integer n, we have the n\times n Identity Matrix to be \mathbf {I}_{n} = (\delta _{i,j}) = \begin {cases}1 &\hbox {if }i=j,\\ 0 &\hbox {if }i\neq j \end {cases} where the components \delta _{i,j} are referred to as the Kronecker Delta.

If n is clear from context, we may suppress the subscript and write \mathbf {I} instead of \mathbf {I}_{n}. Some authors write \mathbf {1} for the identity matrix, because (as we will see) it is analogous to the number 1\in \mathbb {R}.
A Column Vector refers to an n\times 1 matrix.
A Row Vector refers to a 1\times m matrix.
A Vector may refer to either row vectors or column vectors; in these notes on elementary linear algebra, we will reserve the word "vector" specifically for "column vector".

Also note: it is common convention to use superscript indices for column vectors, and subscript indices for row vectors. This allows for the Einstein summation convention to do some stuff automatically for us.

A square matrix \mathbf {A}=(a_{i,j}) for which a_{i,j}=0 when i\neq j is called a Diagonal Matrix. We may write \mathbf {A}=\mathrm {diag}(a_{1,1}, a_{2,2},…, a_{n,n}) to indicate \mathbf {A} is a diagonal matrix.
Caution: some authors write \mathrm {diag}(\mathbf {A}) to refer to the diagonal components of any matrix \mathbf {A}. Just bear this in mind when you run into it "in the wild".
A diagonal matrix \mathbf {A}=(a_{i,j}) for which a_{i,i}=c for all i is called a Scalar Matrix.
The word "scalar" intuitively means "number". We motivated matrices by trying to generalize numbers. Scalar matrices are "the most number-like" among matrices.

Let \mathbf {A}=[a_{i,j}] and \mathbf {B}=[b_{i,j}] be two m\times n matrices. We say \mathbf {A} and \mathbf {B} are Equal if they have identical components in identical positions, i.e., if for each i=1,…,m and j=1,…,n we have a_{i,j}=b_{i,j}. We indicate the matrices are equal by writing \mathbf {A}=\mathbf {B}.

More formally: let \mathbf {A} be an m\times n matrix and \mathbf {B} be an p\times q matrix, if:
m = p and n = q and
(\mathbf {A})_{ij}=(\mathbf {B})_{ij} for all i=1,…,m and j=1,…,n then \mathbf {A} = \mathbf {B}.
If \mathbf {A} and \mathbf {B} are not equal, then we write \mathbf {A}\neq \mathbf {B}.

html:ol.html:li: Will every matrix \mathbf {A} satisfy \mathbf {A} = \mathbf {A}? (Mathematicians call this property "reflexivity", and most "equality-like" relations should have it.)
If \mathbf {A} = \mathbf {B}, is it true or false that \mathbf {B} = \mathbf {A}? Prove it or find a counter-example.

If \mathbf {A} = \mathbf {B} and \mathbf {B} = \mathbf {C}, is it true or false that \mathbf {A} = \mathbf {C}? Prove it or find a counter-example. These first three properties are true for 'equivalence relations' (binary relations which loosely resemble equality).
Let n\neq p. If \mathbf {A} is an 0\times n matrix, and if \mathbf {B} is a 0\times p matrix, then is it true or false that \mathbf {A}=\mathbf {B}?
